subject: Dentistry
statement_full_text:
How vital is the link between the mouth and the body? After witnessing my father's struggle with an infected tooth root and learning that it may have contributed to his existing heart disease, I was curious about the mouth-body connection. This led me to watch a dental talk 'Your oral microbiome is linked to this disease!', in which I learnt that your mouth is a microcosm of systemic health and vital to one's physical and mental wellbeing. Consequently, my appreciation for dentists deepened as I recognised the varied scope of their role. It encompasses much more than just aesthetics; a dentist can detect deeper health issues early through a brief assessment of the mouth. This fascinates me, because not only do dentists help patients feel more comfortable in their smile, they can be life-saving.

My biology course introduced me to the topic of infectious diseases. Linking this to my interest in oral health, I spent time in Bristol Dental School Research Laboratories shadowing PhD students who were conducting research surrounding a particular oral microbe, viridans streptococci (VGS). Some of the research involved producing a prosthetic material covered in nanostructures with a sharp surface. Currently, it can kill around half of the oral bacteria that lands on it; I predict that with developments in biotechnology and further research on the bacteria's mechanisms, closer to ninety percent could be killed. What particularly interested me as it linked to my father's situation was that while VGS is harmless orally, it can lead to cardiovascular infections if it enters the bloodstream, something that can occur during dental procedures. This deepened my understanding of how important it is for dentists to consider the wider systemic implications of oral care. It is this depth and complexity of dentistry that continues to engage me.

Carrying out science experiments in school has given me the opportunity to showcase resilience, self-reflection and critical thinking; these are key attributes of a dental student when navigating challenging course modules and complex clinical skills. To broaden my awareness of the realities of working in dentistry, I spent two weeks shadowing dentists, nurses, lab technicians and admin staff in a private practice and a NHS dental hospital. Noticing the contrast in equipment quality between the two settings, and the resulting difference in patient experience, underscored the inequality in dental care across socioeconomic backgrounds and deepened my commitment to social responsibility as a future dentist. By observing procedures ranging from fillings and extractions to the creation of prosthetics and orthodontic appliances, I gained insight into the teamwork and communication skills essential for four-handed dentistry while developing an appreciation for the practical craftsmanship of this career. Through observing dentists in various specialties, I came to realise that a strong patient-dentist rapport built on trust, empathy and age-appropriate communication is essential for continuity of care. I have developed such interpersonal skills through my role as an academic and pastoral mentor for Year 11 students, providing reassurance, empathy and active listening to form meaningful relationships with them.

Something I often noticed was the adaptability of dentists in what can be stressful situations, particularly when initial treatment plans required revision. This ability to adapt while maintaining composure is a skill I have developed through taekwondo competitions, where unpredictable match times require me to stay calm and adjust quickly. Shadowing a restorative dentist, I observed a complex case in which a patient needed a chrome denture splint to stabilise four loose front teeth. I saw how the dentist constantly and carefully refined the denture using a motor drill to ensure it fit comfortably in the patient's mouth, highlighting the problem-solving aspect of dentistry and the manual precision it demands. The dentist then asked a senior consultant to assess the denture and give a second opinion. The senior consultant's genuine willingness to assist was evident as she offered thorough feedback to the dentist while instilling confidence in their work. This exemplified effective collaboration within the multidisciplinary team to achieve patient-centred care, a clear display of GDC principle 6. Similarly, participating in interschool maths competitions has enhanced my ability to work and lead effectively within a team, which parallels the cohesive teamwork integral to dental settings.

Beyond academics, practicing crochet and guitar in my free time has not only provided an outlet for stress, but has also improved my manual dexterity which is crucial when performing intricate tasks in confined spaces. Jiujitsu trains me to problem-solve quickly under pressure; this is an essential skill in dentistry, where varied conditions require tailored solutions daily. I recognise the physical and mental demands of this course, however to me the reward of restoring the health and confidence of patients massively outweighs these challenges.

feedback_items.weak_passage: How vital is the link between the mouth and the body?
feedback_items.your_feedback: The rhetorical question is unnecessary in a personal statement - it's more something you'd include in a longer essay. This kind of opening isn't needed here.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the rhetorical question and start directly with your personal experience or connection to dentistry.

feedback_items.weak_passage: this fascinates me, because not only do dentists help patients feel more comfortable in their smile, they can be life-saving
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is something you see in every single dentistry statement. It's repetitive in the sense that all applicants include this just to show they know dentistry is important for the whole body. For you, this comes across already in your evidence and development of ideas, so it's not necessary.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence as your understanding of the mouth-body connection is already evident throughout the statement.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The first paragraph is one of the better links between something personal versus linking it to your interest in dentistry. It's definitely the strongest dentistry statement I've seen this year.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider removing the first and last sentences (rhetorical question and the cliche about helping patients), but the rest is spot on.
feedback_items.strong_passage: After witnessing my father's struggle with an infected tooth root and learning that it may have contributed to his existing heart disease, I was curious about the mouth-body connection
feedback_items.why_strong: This is one of the better personal links to dentistry - it's genuine, specific, and shows how your interest developed naturally from a real experience.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Carrying out science experiments in school has given me the opportunity to showcase resilience, self-reflection and critical thinking; these are key attributes of a dental student
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're listing generic traits like resilience, self-reflection, and critical thinking - all traits you'd want to see in every student. Are they as relevant to dentistry? Not particularly. This sentence is the first thing I'd cut if you needed space, because losing it doesn't lose any value from the statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you need to cut characters, remove this sentence entirely as it doesn't add specific value to your dentistry application.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The second paragraph is really well developed. The leveling you've done where you say your biology course introduced you to this, then you did research, and then you developed it - really well done. Very strong paragraph and you don't need to change much because it's all linked.
feedback_items.strong_passage: My biology course introduced me to the topic of infectious diseases. Linking this to my interest in oral health, I spent time in Bristol Dental School Research Laboratories shadowing PhD students
feedback_items.why_strong: The progression from coursework to research experience to deeper understanding shows excellent academic development and initiative. The connection to your father's situation makes it personally meaningful.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Something I often noticed was the adaptability of dentists in what can be stressful situations, particularly when initial treatment plans required revision. This ability to adapt while maintaining composure is a skill I have developed through taekwondo competitions
feedback_items.your_feedback: The taekwondo and jujitsu connections feel quite samey and not as naturally linked as you might think. Knowing you've done those activities, they'll probably say you're quite disciplined and reactive, but it's not like this makes you a good dentist from the tutor's perspective. These points need to be combined together at the end.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Combine the taekwondo and jujitsu points together in 2 sentences at the end, just saying you work great in a team and show discipline through martial arts you've been doing for X years or that you're constantly winning competitions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Similarly, participating in interschool maths competitions has enhanced my ability to work and lead effectively within a team, which parallels the cohesive teamwork integral to dental settings
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole section about maths competitions is becoming unnecessary. This is stuff you can leave them to infer - they don't need you to spell out that competitions build teamwork. This could go in your reference instead, especially if you're constantly winning competitions.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence or drastically shorten it. Consider asking for maths competition achievements to be mentioned in your reference instead.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Beyond academics, practicing crochet and guitar in my free time has not only provided an outlet for stress, but has also improved my manual dexterity
feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't think you should include crochet and guitar in the statement - it's not the best use of space. This is more what you put in an American personal statement, but it's not a direct carry on to dentistry.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the crochet and guitar sentence entirely to make space for more relevant dentistry content.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The whole section from 'something I often noticed' onwards gets a little bit repetitive and goes on and on. You're marrying in taekwondo with jujitsu and lots of it is quite samey, essentially just explaining situations. This needs reorganizing and cutting down.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Reorganize this section: put the restorative dentist example directly after 'initial treatment plans required revision', then combine the martial arts points briefly at the end. Cut the maths competition reference.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The restorative dentist example with the chrome denture splint is good - it shows problem-solving and manual precision well. The part about the senior consultant offering feedback and the GDC principle is also fine, though it's a bit lengthy in the language and could be 15% shorter.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep this example but tighten the language. You've already mentioned collaboration above, so don't reiterate that point - make it sound like point made, point made, rather than mixing up the same points.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Shadowing a restorative dentist, I observed a complex case in which a patient needed a chrome denture splint to stabilise four loose front teeth. I saw how the dentist constantly and carefully refined the denture using a motor drill
feedback_items.why_strong: This shows specific clinical observation with good detail about the problem-solving and manual precision aspects of dentistry.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall it's really good actually. You're a really good writer and your writing style is easy to follow - definitely one of the best writers I've come across this season. The first two sections are very strong - basically the first page is really strong. The second page gets a little bit repetitive and goes on and on, so that part needs tidying up and a critical look.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: The first half is so good, but the second half is a bit more wishy-washy. Cut down the last section, reorganize some of the extracurricular stuff, and remove the hobbies. With those changes, this will be quite complete.

subject: Architecture
statement_full_text:
Studying architecture offers a rare intersection of scientific and creative disciplines. Studying at a UTC has equipped me with a solid foundation in STEM, strengthened by collaborative, employer-led projects. Yet, I have felt the absence of a creative outlet, a space where my passions for science and art coexist; architecture is an interdisciplinary field, where analytical thinking unites with aesthetic intent.

Whilst learning about STEM principles within architecture, I was drawn to Calatrava's Mediopadana. The trigonometric waves formed by its steel portals inspired me, and I wondered how this was modelled during the design process. This drove to me research the capabilities of parametric modelling- where varying inputs generate calculated outputs, allowing for faster paced, adaptable design. Curious about its real-world uses, I learnt the foundation of parametrics by designing a saw handle on Fusion 360. Familiarising myself with CAD confirmed my ambition of using innovative technologies within contemporary practice and reinforced my desire to study architecture.

A pivotal moment in my understanding of design was the National Theatre's 'Stagecraft' project that I completed during my Product Design course. I created a model for 'The Grapes of Wrath,' which offered a unique way to develop my skills working in a reduced scale, and a chance to tell a story through design choices. I was recognised for conveying the timeless, enduring injustice in the play by using ambiguity and minimalism to direct focus onto the actors. This project was my first investigation of the human effects of aesthetics and taught me that design, even at miniature sizes, can be utilised to influence viewers' emotions.

This curiosity about the psychological impacts of space led me to Alain de Botton's 'The Architecture of Happiness.' His critiques of Corbusier's impersonal style of modernism, and insistence that architecture should reflect the values of the time and location in which we build, deeply resonated with me. I applied Botton's thinking to my coursework, designing luxury furniture honouring a local metal working firm's heritage. My analysis of the company's dynamic past will be applied to my piece, materialising his writing by physically embodying the evolving values of the company through convertibility and multi-functionality.

Two summer schools broadened my expectations of university study. In Sheffield, I explored urban regeneration, selecting a building from the skyline and proposing a new use for the space- an exercise in line with sustainable approaches to adaptive reuse which I encountered at UTC Leeds: a former press-working factory remodelled into a college. At St John's, Cambridge, I designed a temporary pavilion; I was inspired by Chinese tourism in the area, so referenced cultural motifs and provided exhibition spaces for local Asian artists. My aim was to celebrate the history of Asian figures in the city and emphasise the talents of underrepresented voices.

Attending UKREIFF expanded my understanding of architecture's social responsibility. Notably, a workshop led by BDP Leeds explored inclusive design for neurodiverse and disabled people, with Southmead Hospital as a case study. Its use of natural light, ventilation, and intuitive way finding, exemplified how architecture should prioritise users' needs, which strongly aligns with my interest in human centric design.

This October, I will undertake a placement with Watson Batty, shadowing professionals and working on an independent project. I hope to consolidate what I have learnt thus far, putting it into practice in a professional setting, and growing my skills in drawing and model making.

Collectively, these experiences have formed my view of architecture and its wide-reaching impact on engineering, environment, and emotion. I am looking forward to deepening my knowledge in an academic setting, and growing my technical skill set, to design meaningful and responsive buildings.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall, you don't have any particularly super strong sections - nothing very technical, nothing super developed. It's largely descriptive. If I took away filler language and wordy writing, you'd lose about 30% of the statement. It's not very dense with content - there's a difference between using 4000 characters to explain something new every step versus using characters to fill and guide.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Have more confidence in your ideas and explain them out more. Compared to other architecture statements this year, this is bang on average in quality. The cohort's been very strong.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Studying architecture offers a rare intersection of scientific and creative disciplines. Studying at a UTC has equipped me with a solid foundation in STEM, strengthened by collaborative, employer-led projects. Yet, I have felt the absence of a creative outlet, a space where my passions for science and art coexist; architecture is an interdisciplinary field, where analytical thinking unites with aesthetic intent.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're repeating the relationship between science and creative disciplines again and again. You say science/creative, then STEM/employer projects, then science/art, then analytical/aesthetic. You've used 5 lines just to say science meets creativity multiple times. This is a massive waste of space.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Make this one clean sentence: 'Architecture fascinates me because it's the intersection of science and creative disciplines. I experienced this at UTC where I [name STEM work] and [name example project].' Full stop.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This drove to me research the capabilities of parametric modelling- where varying inputs generate calculated outputs, allowing for faster paced, adaptable design
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your explanation of parametric modelling is not correct or comprehensive - you've picked upon a couple of bits. You say you learned the foundations by designing a saw handle and familiarized yourself with CAD, but you haven't actually explained step by step what you did for this project. They want to know what project you built, what limitations you ran into, how you got over that, and what kind of student you'll be at university.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Actually explain what you did with the saw handle project in detail. End this section with a book or designer you admire, saying you've looked at what they're designing and you're excited to explore this further at university.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was recognised for conveying the timeless, enduring injustice in the play by using ambiguity and minimalism to direct focus onto the actors
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is very vague. Who recognized you - did you win an award, was it the audience? Without a subject it's confusing. Second, you say you used ambiguity and minimalism but don't explain what you actually did. Throughout the statement you're lacking specificity - it's always in vague general terms like 'there was ambiguity, there was minimalism' but how? You're not telling me.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain exactly who recognized you and what specific design choices you made. Tell me what the exact thing was that you designed and how it influenced viewers' emotions, rather than just summarizing.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This project was my first investigation of the human effects of aesthetics and taught me that design, even at miniature sizes, can be utilised to influence viewers' emotions
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't need this summary sentence. With a personal statement being short, you don't need the summary and then the explanation - just go straight into the explanation of what you actually did.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence and instead use the space to explain the specific design choices and their effects.

feedback_items.weak_passage: His critiques of Corbusier's impersonal style of modernism, and insistence that architecture should reflect the values of the time and location in which we build, deeply resonated with me
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is your only academic paragraph apart from the second one. It begins to be a bit academic with the book mention, but it's not super developed - it's just 'here's a book and I also think architecture should reflect these values' with no real explanation, buildup of why, or examples, or case study, or something applied. You're just saying it generally resonates with you, which is not the strongest point.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add explanation of why you agree, include an example or case study, and show deeper engagement with the ideas beyond just saying they resonate.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My analysis of the company's dynamic past will be applied to my piece, materialising his writing by physically embodying the evolving values of the company through convertibility and multi-functionality
feedback_items.your_feedback: This gets a bit vague and too wordy. This entire sentence should just be something like 'I applied/embodied the company's history in my piece by creating features that could be used for multiple purposes, such as X, Y, Z.' You're left wondering what actually happened here.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Simplify to: 'I embodied the company's history in my piece by [give specific example of convertibility/multifunctionality].' Be concrete about what you actually made.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My aim was to celebrate the history of Asian figures in the city and emphasise the talents of underrepresented voices
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is just not academic. Get rid of that. The summer schools section is fine in terms of content and it's actual things you did, which is nice. But it's a lot of 'I did, did, did' - just listing things.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove that aim sentence. Instead add another sentence that explains something more nuanced and technical - like 'we had to balance X and Y because of the resources we had' or something more technical rather than just listing accomplishments.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Its use of natural light, ventilation, and intuitive way finding, exemplified how architecture should prioritise users' needs
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your statement is largely descriptive - you're just listing things out. I'd rather you focus on say natural light and explain why that's important, or bring in a psychology case study, or show the impact before and after with data, or bring in an architect's opinion as source material.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Pick one element (like natural light) and develop it deeply with evidence, rather than listing multiple surface-level points.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This October, I will undertake a placement with Watson Batty, shadowing professionals and working on an independent project. I hope to consolidate what I have learnt thus far, putting it into practice in a professional setting, and growing my skills in drawing and model making.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Cut this - you haven't done this yet so it's not very useful because you haven't learned from it. You could include this in your reference or in the work experience section of your UCAS application since it's technically a placement, but here it doesn't have a place.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this entirely. Only include experiences you've actually completed and learned from.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Collectively, these experiences have formed my view of architecture and its wide-reaching impact on engineering, environment, and emotion. I am looking forward to deepening my knowledge in an academic setting, and growing my technical skill set, to design meaningful and responsive buildings.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a repeat of the first paragraph - just a list of things. The three things (engineering, environment, emotion) don't even flow that well together. The last sentence is meaningless.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove or completely rewrite this conclusion. It adds nothing substantive.

feedback_items.your_feedback: If I were to tell you to give this another go, make it more academic, bring in more technical detail, bring in more applied examples, develop more, less listing and doing, focus on one thing and develop your points. Your statement is fine - no red flags, so don't feel like you have to make any of these changes.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on depth over breadth. Pick fewer examples but explain them thoroughly with technical detail and analysis rather than listing many things superficially.

subject: History and French
statement_full_text:
I am fascinated by other cultures, whether they be present-day or historical. I have found that, despite the at times acrimonious Anglo-Franco relationship, the French culture offers rich historical and linguistic insight into the formation of its neighbouring nation. Reading an article from the University of Nottingham highlighted to me the impact of the French language on English lexis: dating back to the arrival of the Anglo-Norman aristocracy and remaining entrenched in modern day vocabulary. I reinforced my understanding of the significance of language exchange by exploring the need for greater levels of bilingualism in the UK in my EPQ.

When staying with host families on French and Spanish exchanges, I was able to see the effects of history abroad and particularly how the taboo of the Vichy Regime persists in French societal attitudes. This challenged the impression I had formed from literature and film (A. Doerr's All the Light We Cannot See) and non-fiction (In the Mouth of the Wolf — a play about French SOE officer Francis Cammaerts) which presented to me a venerated misconstruction that wartime France was united in resistance to Nazi occupation. Exploring the subtleties of France's ambiguous association with both the Allies and Axis powers inspired me to complete my own research project on F. Cammaerts and enter the YHA essay competition with my findings. I was particularly enthralled by Cammaerts' almost paradoxical determination to asseverate his pacifism whilst organising guerilla warfare on behalf of the allies. Yet, I questioned the typicality of this individual's compelling story and so will be researching the extent of French collaboration and resistance in WW2 further in my History NEA.

Reading verse such as Paroles by Prévert has heightened my appreciation for the lilting euphonies of the French language, whilst reading Les Justes by Camus and consequently L'Étranger has helped me become more accustomed to the syntax of real-life French. Tackling French philosophy (Cinq Méditations Sur la Beauté by F. Cheng) has reminded me of the boundless levels of academia that language learning provides and motivated me to pursue a more sophisticated command of the language. Maths A-Level has instilled in me the rigour of learning and applying formulae, which is necessary for language acquisition.

When reading historical literature such as A Line in the Sand by J. Barr and Lawrence of Arabia by R. Fiennes, in advance of my Y13 Middle East unit, it was intriguing to notice the disparities in the authors' interpretations, in which Fiennes presented a somewhat discourteous glorification of Britain, France, and the USA's political disenfranchisement of the Arabs. Similarly, when visiting the San Francisco City Museum, I was struck by the disingenuous treatment of the Chinese population during the creation of the transcontinental railroad, who were omitted from history by the White settlers, despite making up 90% of the workforce. This seemed staggering for such a seemingly righteous country, in comparison to the vast progression of justice and enlightenment a century earlier in Germany, which I learnt about on the languages 'Access to Bristol' course.

To improve my oral skills, I listen to podcasts such as Escargot and HugoDécrypte, which I have then been able to exercise by winning the SW languages debating competition and spending a week working in a library in France. In doing the latter, I observed the centrality of stories, both historical and fictional, to the local municipality and was reminded of the escapism that exploring alternate narratives provides. I recognised the importance of local, individual stories by reading History: A Very Short Introduction and by volunteering at my local Heritage Centre. In my café job, I have grown to value communication when managing staff and customers. Similarly, this principle has been key for me when mentoring younger students in French and Spanish and also for 11+ exams.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I like the statement much better now and the sections are good. The one main thing to look at is the style of writing - you write in a somewhat wordy way. I've rewritten your first paragraph to show you how to improve logical flow and sentence structuring.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on improving logical flow and sentence structure. Get to the point first, because sometimes the point is there but hard to find. After that, be more critical about what else to include.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I am fascinated by other cultures, whether they be present-day or historical. I have found that, despite the at times acrimonious Anglo-Franco relationship, the French culture offers rich historical and linguistic insight into the formation of its neighbouring nation.
feedback_items.your_feedback: The way this is written makes it hard to understand your point. The two sentences don't link very well, so it's confusing. Because you have 'formation of its neighbouring nation' last, there's a lot of vagueness. You're trying to say we can learn about Britain by studying France, which makes sense, but the order is confusing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rewrite as: 'I'm fascinated by all cultures, both modern and historical, and everything we can learn from them. Despite the at times acrimonious Anglo-French relationship, we can learn much about the formation of Britain by studying the rich historical and linguistic cultures of France.' This links the sentences better and is more direct.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading an article from the University of Nottingham highlighted to me the impact of the French language on English lexis: dating back to the arrival of the Anglo-Norman aristocracy and remaining entrenched in modern day vocabulary.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You don't quote the university, you quote the academic - I think you mean Isabel Roth's article. Also, I'm not sure what your point is. You have a general point (French impacted English) followed by general detail (goes back to Norman times), and it doesn't really work. The detail isn't a nuanced point, just another general thing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rewrite to cite the actual academic (e.g., 'An article by Isabel Roth explored the impact of the French language on English lexis'). Then instead of another general detail, include something more specific and interesting about a particular impact, not just that it dates back to Norman times.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I reinforced my understanding of the significance of language exchange by exploring the need for greater levels of bilingualism in the UK in my EPQ
feedback_items.your_feedback: The connection to your EPQ isn't smooth. After improving the previous sentences, you should finish with something like 'Building on this, I wrote an EPQ arguing for the need for greater levels of bilingualism in the UK.' This connects much better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Improve the transition: 'Building on this, I wrote an EPQ arguing for the need for greater levels of bilingualism in the UK.'

feedback_items.your_feedback: A lot of the sections and content you've got is good. The last little thing you need to do is improve your logical flow and structuring of sentences so you're getting to the point first. Sometimes I'm searching for the point even though it's in there.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on putting your main point at the start of sentences, then adding supporting detail. Avoid burying your argument in complex sentence structures.

subject: History and French
statement_full_text:
The convoluted Anglo-Franco relationship offers rich historical and linguistic insight into the formation of modern-day England. Reflecting on the fact that England, rather ironically, prides itself on its independence from Europe and its historical dominance sparked a great fascination for me. I have relished discovering the deep-rooted exchange of language, customs, and values between England and our neighbouring nation, and it is this interdependence that I wish to understand in greater detail through my university studies.

Exploring France's involvement in World War Two through both fiction (A. Doerr's All the Light We Cannot See, which primarily focuses on a resistance network in Saint-Malo) and non-fiction (In the Mouth of the Wolf — a play about French SOE officer Francis Cammaerts) highlighted to me the subtleties of France's ambiguous association with both the Allies and Axis powers. Seeing France's fluctuation between being England's ally yet also returning to the notion of being traditional enemies inspired me to complete my own research project on Cammaerts and enter the YHA essay competition with my findings. I was impelled to research this further by choosing French collaboration under the Vichy Regime for my History NEA.

The critical evaluation skills I practise when synthesising sources and reaching refined outcomes are directly applicable to languages. The significance of nuanced articulation became apparent to me while staying with host families on Spanish and French exchanges; I was met with frustration when my lack of vocabulary limited my ability to express myself, which drove me towards achieving fluency in foreign languages. I have exposed myself to different registers of French literature; reading verse such as Paroles by Prévert has heightened my appreciation for the lilting euphonies of the French language, whilst reading Les Justes by Camus and consequently L'Étranger have helped me become more attuned to syntaxes of real-life French. Tackling French philosophy (Cinq Méditations Sur la Beauté by F. Cheng) has reminded me of the boundless levels of academia that language learning provides and motivated me to pursue a more sophisticated command of the language.

When reading historical literature such as A Line in the Sand by J. Barr and Lawrence of Arabia by R. Fiennes, in advance of my Y13 Middle East unit, it was intriguing to notice the disparities in the authors' interpretations, in which Fiennes presented a somewhat discourteous glorification of Britain, France, and the USA's political disenfranchisement of the Arabs. Similarly, when visiting the San Francisco City Museum, I was struck by the disingenuous treatment of the Chinese population during the creation of the transcontinental railroad, who were omitted from history by the White settlers, despite making up 90% of the workforce. This seemed staggering for such a seemingly righteous country, in comparison to the vast progression of justice and enlightenment a century earlier in Germany, which I learnt about on the languages 'Access to Bristol' course.

To improve my oral skills, I listen to podcasts such as Escargot and HugoDécrypte, which I have then been able to exercise by winning the SW languages debating competition and spending a week working in a library in France. In doing the latter, I observed the centrality of stories, both historical and fictional, to the local municipality and was reminded of the escapism that exploring alternate narratives provides. I recognised the importance of local, individual stories by reading History: A Very Short Introduction and by volunteering at my local Heritage Centre. In my café job, I have grown to value communication when managing staff and customers.

Similarly, this principle has been key for me when mentoring younger students in French and Spanish and for their 11+ exams.

It is the extensive skills that History and French provide that captivates me and necessitates me to pursue my studies further.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The convoluted Anglo-Franco relationship
feedback_items.your_feedback: Convoluted is not the best word because it raises more questions than it answers. It's your interpretation of that relationship, not something everyone agrees on. When you use a word like that, it's too simplistic and you have to go into more detail. Use something like 'the at times acrimonious' relationship instead, which is more accurate and acceptable.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change 'convoluted' to 'at times acrimonious' or similar phrasing that's less interpretive and more universally accepted.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reflecting on the fact that England, rather ironically, prides itself on its independence from Europe and its historical dominance sparked a great fascination for me
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're assuming I'll agree that England prides itself on independence, which isn't necessarily true - based on Brexit, at least half the country is against it. This is strange to bring in. You say 'rather ironically' but why is it ironic? If you explained it that would be fine, but because you don't, it's problematic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove this sentence, explain why it's ironic with evidence, or bring a source to support the claim about England's pride in independence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have relished discovering the deep-rooted exchange of language, customs, and values between England and our neighbouring nation, and it is this interdependence that I wish to understand in greater detail
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a little bit limiting for your university studies. The whole first paragraph could be rethought - it's not the strongest start.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rethink the entire first paragraph to make it less limiting and more compelling as an opening.

feedback_items.weak_passage: impelled
feedback_items.your_feedback: You probably mean 'compelled' not 'impelled.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change 'impelled' to 'compelled.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: (A. Doerr's All the Light We Cannot See, which primarily focuses on a resistance network in Saint-Malo)
feedback_items.your_feedback: If you're not going to extract an insight from a book and use it to develop an idea, then just leave it as the title. There's no point giving a quick summary - either the tutor knows it or can look it up. It should be about your insight, not a summary that isn't interesting.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove the bracketed summary or replace it with an actual insight you gained from the book.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Seeing France's fluctuation between being England's ally yet also returning to the notion of being traditional enemies
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fluctuation doesn't quite make sense as a word choice here. That whole sentence is a bit nothingy. You should use the phrase suggested before, like 'the acrimonious relationship' - that would sum it up better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace this awkward phrasing with clearer language about the complex Anglo-French relationship.

feedback_items.weak_passage: inspired me to complete my own research project on Cammaerts and enter the YHA essay competition with my findings. I was impelled to research this further by choosing French collaboration under the Vichy Regime for my History NEA
feedback_items.your_feedback: You literally shove these two projects in at the end, but they should actually be the bulk of that paragraph or the basis of it. The stuff above is much less useful. Can you tell me what the research project was and the conclusion of the essay? Can you say the conclusion of the NEA and exactly what you did?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand dramatically on both the research project and NEA. Include conclusions, key findings, and specific points you explored. These should be the centerpiece of the paragraph, not afterthoughts.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The critical evaluation skills I practise when synthesising sources and reaching refined outcomes are directly applicable to languages
feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole first sentence you need to get rid of. Synthesising sources doesn't make any sense actually. The whole first sentence is just weird.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence entirely and start the paragraph differently.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The significance of nuanced articulation became apparent to me while staying with host families
feedback_items.your_feedback: Nuanced articulation is a bit random and doesn't require that level of language. You're overly going hard with vocabulary. The whole purpose of language is to get your idea across first and foremost - if it's creating confusion, it's not the right word to use.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Simplify to something like 'I'm particularly interested in language' or 'The importance of vocabulary became clear during exchanges' - use simpler, clearer language.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I have exposed myself to different registers of French literature; reading verse such as Paroles by Prévert has heightened my appreciation for the lilting euphonies of the French language
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're just listing off books without bringing out insights. 'Exposed myself to different literature' is a bit much - you can just say you read them. 'Lilting euphonies' is also too much. If you're going to mention books, bring out some insight and say what was really interesting, not just summarize.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Instead of listing, pick one or two books and explain a specific insight or interesting aspect from each. Replace flowery language with concrete observations.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Tackling French philosophy (Cinq Méditations Sur la Beauté by F. Cheng) has reminded me of the boundless levels of academia that language learning provides and motivated me to pursue a more sophisticated command of the language
feedback_items.your_feedback: That whole sentence adds nothing. This whole paragraph can be reworked quite a bit - you're just listing off books without insights.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence or replace with a specific insight from the philosophy text.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This paragraph was much better actually. It was more contained and developed. I understand what your thoughts are because you talk about how something seemed staggering for such a righteous country but then in comparison you've got this progression. Much better developed and the whole paragraph works quite well.
feedback_items.strong_passage: When reading historical literature such as A Line in the Sand by J. Barr and Lawrence of Arabia by R. Fiennes, in advance of my Y13 Middle East unit, it was intriguing to notice the disparities in the authors' interpretations
feedback_items.why_strong: This paragraph shows comparative analysis and critical thinking - you're evaluating different interpretations and making connections across historical contexts.

feedback_items.your_feedback: That paragraph is fine actually. Not bad.
feedback_items.strong_passage: To improve my oral skills, I listen to podcasts such as Escargot and HugoDécrypte, which I have then been able to exercise by winning the SW languages debating competition
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows practical application of language skills with concrete achievements.

feedback_items.weak_passage: It is the extensive skills that History and French provide that captivates me and necessitates me to pursue my studies further
feedback_items.your_feedback: Obviously you want to remove that last sentence - it doesn't really do anything.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this sentence entirely.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The last two paragraphs are fine. It's the first 3 that are more problematic. Maybe take another look at those. There are a couple bits you could cut, like the last sentence obviously.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus revision efforts on the first three paragraphs - improve word choice, remove flowery language, develop the research projects more fully, and bring out actual insights from the books you mention.

subject: Mathematics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

Mathematics is widely considered the sole universal language, underpinning everything we do and explaining the world we live in. It transcends geographical or cultural boundaries and unifies people in a way that inspires me. I came to really appreciate the subject during my accelerated study of the A-Level in one year; the rigour and beauty of it is unlike anything. Uncovering new links between concepts, experiencing the light-bulb moment where everything clicks and then finding a new pathway to solve a problem is truly addictive.

The further you study, the more you see how important the basics are. Pascal's Triangle seemed to be nothing more than a trivial array of numbers to my 11-year-old self, but I felt enlightened when I saw how this could be applied in several real-world places, like as the binomial coefficients in statistics to find probability with repeated trials.

I'm fascinated with how mathematical ideas appear in the most unexpected of places. One example is 'Dudley's Happiness Function', created by microeconomist Dr Julia Shvets – a model to find the optimal driving speed which maximises joy and minimises pain. Some would call this common sense, but I found using maths in such an everyday scenario to be satisfying.

How have your qualifications and studies prepared you for this course or subject?

Completing the entirety of A-Level mathematics in Year 12 strengthened my resolve, preparing me for the university pace. Learning topics at this speed fulfilled my desire to absorb all the knowledge I could, oftentimes leading me to explore further than the specification. For example, I was nominated to sit the Mathematical Olympiad for Girls which had styles of problems I had never encountered before, such as a combinatorics question on which I gained full marks. It felt invigorating to be faced with such intensive questions and attempt several different approaches until one worked. This led me to read Robin Wilson's 'A Very Short Introduction to Combinatorics', where I discovered an interest in enumeration problems and was surprised by how this links to my study of isomerism in A-Level Chemistry.

For my Industrial Cadets Gold Award, I led the mathematical component within my team to build a tidal energy generator. I was responsible for the gear system, calculating tidal speeds from data I sourced from the local harbour, and determining the optimal gear ratio. After many of my initial ideas failed, the genuine rush of finding the perfect solution is exactly what drives my passion for tackling new problems. Applying maths to address prevalent problems faced by our society, with environmentalism coming increasingly to the forefront, really inspired me with what I could do in the future.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education and why were these experiences useful?

In Cambridge's Women in Maths Programme, Dr Henry Bradford's lecture on algorithmic methods to find new large primes sparked my interest in RSA cryptography. I found it intriguing, albeit concerning as with advances in quantum computing, the process of factorising large primes from a product could be done alarmingly quickly, thus putting our banking, emails and overall privacy at great risk.

I wrote an article for my school's science magazine on the prevailing debate whether maths was invented or discovered, including my further research on primes. The North American Periodical Cicada only ever lives a prime number of years, ensuring their emergence rarely coincides with that of their predators. In my eyes, this is an explicit display of maths embedded innately in nature and not something that mankind can begin to fabricate.

Tutoring GCSE maths students showed me how explaining basic concepts from different angles can offer new insights, even to people who mastered them years ago. Being able to cater your teachings to help different types of minds understand has been rewarding for me.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Mathematics is widely considered the sole universal language, underpinning everything we do and explaining the world we live in. It transcends geographical or cultural boundaries and unifies people in a way that inspires me. I came to really appreciate the subject during my accelerated study of the A-Level in one year; the rigour and beauty of it is unlike anything. Uncovering new links between concepts, experiencing the light-bulb moment where everything clicks and then finding a new pathway to solve a problem is truly addictive.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your first couple of paragraphs don't tell me a lot - I've seen it so many times, tutors will have seen it even more. All of this could just be 'I love maths.' Without actual examples or development where you take a math problem and explain exactly how you solved it and other ways people have looked at it, it's not that interesting. This could apply to pretty much any subject - English, chemistry, physics, biology are all the same.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Start with your third paragraph instead (Dudley's Happiness Function) - that's a wonderful start, nice and short and genuine. Replace the generic opening with the Pascal's Triangle example, but take it to the next level - talk about different models and programs that use it as a basis, then extend to university level and current affairs cutting edge research.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The third paragraph with Dudley's Happiness Function is great - very nice, neat, and immediately bringing in an example. 'I have always been fascinated by how mathematical ideas appear in the most unexpected of places. One example is...' This is a wonderful start.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use this as your opening paragraph instead of the current first two paragraphs.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I'm fascinated with how mathematical ideas appear in the most unexpected of places. One example is 'Dudley's Happiness Function', created by microeconomist Dr Julia Shvets – a model to find the optimal driving speed which maximises joy and minimises pain
feedback_items.why_strong: This is specific, interesting, and shows genuine engagement with mathematics in an unexpected context. It's concise and compelling.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Completing the entirety of A-Level mathematics in Year 12 strengthened my resolve, preparing me for the university pace. Learning topics at the speed fulfilled my desire to absorb all the knowledge I could
feedback_items.your_feedback: Completing A Level mathematics in year 12 should really be in your reference, so check with your tutor to make sure it's in there. It's a bit of a waste of space for you to include because it's just a fact, and a lot of people do that so it's not particularly noteworthy.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this and let your reference cover it. Use the space for more academic content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: such as a combinatorics question on which I gained full marks. It felt invigorating to be faced with such intensive questions and attempt several different approaches until one worked
feedback_items.your_feedback: Rather than just saying you gained full marks, it's better if you could say how you solved it. You mention several different approaches - tell me which approach worked and why others failed, then you went to something else. This is what you're missing - that leveling of 'yes I solved this, then I searched out more stuff, here's more.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain the actual problem-solving process - which approach worked, why others failed, how you worked through it. Then show how you extended beyond this.

feedback_items.weak_passage: where I discovered an interest in enumeration problems and was surprised by how this links to my study of isomerism in A-Level Chemistry
feedback_items.your_feedback: I wouldn't bring in A Level chemistry personally. This is a maths personal statement at the end of the day - you don't need to justify your other subjects.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove the chemistry reference. Just expand on the enumeration problems themselves - talk about one particular problem in detail.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The genuine rush of finding the perfect solution is exactly what drives my passion for tackling new problems
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is kind of a choice thing - it doesn't really add a lot, but it's a nice filler sentence. Not the end of the world.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep if you have space, but it's expendable if you need room for more substantive content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Applying maths to address prevalent problems faced by our society, with environmentalism coming increasingly to the forefront, really inspired me with what I could do in the future
feedback_items.your_feedback: That is a bit of a random sentence. If you're gonna say that, you need to talk about a specific thing where you say how maths is going to solve a particular problem in society or the environment. I don't think you're wrong, but you need to give me something specific there.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove this or replace with a specific example of how mathematics addresses an environmental problem.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This last section with the lecture on primes and RSA cryptography is fairly interesting and decent. The article you wrote sounds really interesting as well. This paragraph is actually probably your cleanest - it's fine.
feedback_items.strong_passage: In Cambridge's Women in Maths Programme, Dr Henry Bradford's lecture on algorithmic methods to find new large primes sparked my interest in RSA cryptography. I found it intriguing, albeit concerning as with advances in quantum computing, the process of factorising large primes from a product could be done alarmingly quickly
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows engagement with current mathematical research and real-world applications, with good understanding of implications.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Tutoring GCSE maths students showed me how explaining basic concepts from different angles can offer new insights, even to people who mastered them years ago
feedback_items.your_feedback: The tutoring stuff is probably the only thing I'm like, yeah, if you could replace that with something else more mathsy, that would be good.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace with more mathematical content. Go to UCL maths admissions tutors' CV pages, look at what papers or fields they're researching, choose one and do a mini paragraph on that.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You've done well to have the right amount of extracurricular stuff like competitions. What you're missing is a bit more academic reading, lectures, MOOCs - that kind of moment. If you end up cutting the first two paragraphs, you'll have a lot of space. Include one more academic resource.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Cut the generic opening two paragraphs. Start with Dudley's Function. Add more academic content - look at what your target universities' tutors are researching and engage with that area. You have good extracurriculars but need more academic reading/lectures.
